title: Rob Roy - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: To avenge thisquarrel, the Laird of MacGregor assembled his clan, to the number ofthree or four hundred men, and marched towards Luss from the banks ofLoch Long, by a pass called _Raid na Gael,_ or the Highlandman's Pass.

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Roseneath, a smaller isle, lies much higher up the firth, and towards itswestern shore, near the opening of the lake called the Gare Loch, and notfar from Loch Long and Loch Scant, or the Holy Loch, which wind from themountains of the Western Highlands to join the estuary of the Clyde.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Loch Long looking beautiful as we returned.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We turnedback and went up Loch Long, which I remembered so well, and which is so beautiful.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: 249left, and proceeded a little way up Loch Goil,which opens into Loch Long, and is very fine;it seems extraordinary to have such deep waterin a narrow loch, and so immediately below themountains, which are very rocky.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We have been turning about agood deal since yesterday, for we went by Arranand Holy Lsland, and then left Little and GreatCumbray to our left, and went up to Dumba/rtonand back, and on to Loch Long, and then to Rothsay, leaving Arran to our left ; then, after passingArran, we entered Loch Fyne.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Loch Long is indeed splendid, 15 mUes inlength, surrounded by grand hills, with such beautiful outlines, and very green — all so differentfrom the eastern part of Scotland — the loch winding along most beautifully, so as to seem closed attimes.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Steamed past Greenock, and went ontoward Loch Long, passing Roseneath to the right,where the present Duke and Duchess of Argylllive.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: is an arm of the sea, six miles in length by from one to two in breadth, which branches off from Loch Long in a northwesterly  direction at Argyle's Bowling-Grecn.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: the head of Loch Long, and, crossing the water of Taing, enters Argylcshire.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Loch Long is not more than a mile in breadth ; and in sailing up we have an excellent view of the Arroquhar range of hills, which present so formidable an appearance when descending upon Loch Lomond from Loch Katrine.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: on leaving the pier of Greenock a sail of about half an hour brings him to the mouth of Loch Long, an arm of the sea, about 24 miles in length, and about 2 in breadth, which, striking off from the Frith of Clyde, at first in a northerly, and afterwards in a north-easterly direction, separates the counties of Argyle and Dumbarton.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: But the most common way is by steamer t from Glasgow or Greenock up Loch Long to Arroquhar or Loch Goil-head.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On the point cf land between Loch Long and Holy Loch, is Strone, a modem watering-place.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Of these the most conspicuous are the beautiful Gareloch, with its ducal palace embowered amid ancestral trees ; Loch Long, darkening as it ascends beneath the frowning  shadows of the Arroquhar hills, and at length almost mingling its briny flood with the sweet waters of Loch Lomond ; the Holy Loch, a solemn-looking place, where the noble femilj of Argyll has its burial vault.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: ings to Loch Long, Holy Loch, the Garel'^ch, and the rugged tops of " Argyle's Bowling Green."

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: It is not large, and somewhat resembles Arroquhar at the head of Loch Long.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: From its position it may be said to command the Gareloch, Loch Long, Loch Goil, and Loch Lomond ; and this, together with its great accessibility by steamers from Glasgow and Greenock, render it a most agreeable residence.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The southmost conducts to Kilcreggan, the middle one, a little further north, to Loch Long, a little above Cove, and the northmost  to Loch Long, opposite Ardentinny.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The southmost conducts to Kilcreggan, the middle one, a little further north, to Loch Long, a little above Cove, and the northmost  to Loch Long, opposite Ardentinny.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Kilcreggan, Cove (Loch Long), Kilmun, and Strone (Holy Loch), Dunoon and Innellan, Innerkip and Wemyss Bay, Largs, Millport, and Rothesay.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands /
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: Roseneath occupies the ground between the Gare Lochand Loch Long.

title: A year in Europe,
author: Moore, Walter William
snippet: Duchess of Hamilton, up Loch Long, Loch Goil, and the Kyles of Bute, with alternating  showers and sunshine, getting charming views of the lovely scenery that abounds about the Firth of Clyde.

title: A year in Europe,
author: Moore, Walter William
snippet: THE fog was so thick the morning we steamed down the ill-smelling Clyde, and out through the Kyles of Bute, that we could see nothing whatever, and had to content ourselves as best we could with the tantalizing recollections of one member of the party, who on a former occasion had made an excursion with some five hundred other persons, delegates to the Glasgow Council and their friends, on the elegant steamer, Duchess of Hamilton, up Loch Long, Loch Goil, and the Kyles of Bute, with alternating  showers and sunshine, getting charming views of the lovely scenery that abounds about the Firth of Clyde.
